Fun concept, flawed executionThis is a game where you make tea. You control a robo-arm and must pick up a teabag, put it in a cup, add hot water, then include any other stuff as instructed by a piece of paper, like sugar or milk. It sounded fun to me because I thought controlling the robo-arm would be amusing and challenging to some degree; unfortunately the controls, mouse feedback, and just about everything else actually, are way too broken for this game to be playable or taken seriously.Some of the flaws1) Objects weigh too littleEverything is as light as a feather. So when you even slightly touch them, they start to topple. This includes the hot water dispenser which is a huge bulky object. The "lightness" makes it virtually impossible to do anything.2) The mouse is far too sensitiveMoving even 1mm (yes, you heard right - that's millimetres we're talking about) with your mouse results in a HUGE movement by the robo-arm, so much so that it's nigh impossible to move properly. You practically have to "tiptoe" with your mouse movement - like maybe 0.1mm or less per move. The same thing happens if you move too fast - the arm will zoom rapidly, knocking down everything in its path.3) The fingers cannot grip properlyForget trying to actually pick up the teacup or anything else for that matter - the hand and its fingers are practically useless - too "weak", and most of the time not angled correctly (wrist rotation only works sideways and not vertically). 												Clearly inspired by 2013's Surgeon Simulator 2013 (which the developer at least have the decency to acknowledge), this game has the quirkiness and tongue-in-cheek playfulness of that title, but with none of the personality, finese or fun. Robotic limbs are pretty damn bad*ss (one day I really hope we'll see some robotic *sses, too! Maybe I'll even get one myself if I'm real lucky), and I guess tea is pretty decent as well, but here, they really don't blend very well at all.Controlling the robotic arm of a recovering amputee (because they're classy with their set-up like that), you must fulfill the order required to make a satisfactory cup of tea and try your best not to completely wreck the gaff in the process. The arm itself is somewhat unwieldy and very unintuitive to direct, with the motions of the fingers being a particular bugbear. In Surgeon Simulator the controls were laid out in a way that made sense and soon felt pretty natural to use, and the solid, slightly stubby fingers meant picking up items was mostly quick and straightforward. Here, however, an awkward control scheme mixed with long, gangly, slow-moving digits that don't even close properly makes for the majority of the challenge as you struggle massively with picking up anything and wrestling with pretty much every single object you try to interact with.There isn't really much more to the game other than grabbing a cup, putting some items into it, moving the cup around, adding some liquids then placing the cup on a platter. And after you've done that once, you've essentially seen all the game has to offer. You can always smash everything up or flip the table (possibly breaking the arm as you do), but other than that, nada. Depending on how quickly the controls click with you or how lucky you get, you could probably finish this in anything from 10 to 40 minutes (I think I completed every achievement bar one in half an hour), and after that you've no real reason to revisit it since there's nothing else on offer except to retry the task with slightly different orders or quantities of ingredients.More frustrating and annoying than bad, given how little content there is here, and how not particularly fun it is, there's no way I could recommend it at full price, and, if anything, fives euros seems like a bit of a p*ss take if you ask me. If controlling the thing wasn't so unneccesarily cumbersome, or there was more content beyond a single "quest" to complete, I'd likely endorse it, but as it stands, it's probably worth something closer to 50c. Though there could be an argument made for it being free. If it's on sale and you just have to see what the fuss is about, maybe it's worth briefly investigating. But in any other circumstances, there's really so many other, better things you could be wasting your time and money on than this.

												Please read the whole review before flagging as helpful/not helpful. It's at times like these that I wish Steam had the option for a neutral review.Paying homage to fan favourite and viral classic Surgeon Simulator 2013, Ampu-Tea (LOL VERY PUNNY) is a tea-making simulator. Like SS2013, you need to use both your hands to control a solitary left arm. (Which, in this case, is robotic, and unlike SS2013, it can be VERY fragile. Don't hit it too much on stuff or it will break and you will have to restart the level.) The control schemes for both games are roughly very similar, and this review will be littered with a lot of comparisons between the two games.Unfortunately, while SS2013's controls, though awkward, still had reasonable control, this game practically throws all semblance of control out of the window. You'll be in for a torrid time if you try to grab anything with your hand's fingers. I've tried quite a lot of times and I have to say that I've NEVER, in my 2.5 hours of playing this, successfully gripped or picked up the cup. Or anything else for that matter. I've had to resort to pushing the cup around with my arm then pushing the tea ingredients into/near the cup.Also unlike SS2013, you can only do one thing in this game, and that is to make tea. This makes the game potentially frightfully short, depending on how skilled or lucky you are. All you can change is whether or not you add milk or sugar. There are 2 achievements where you need to add milk and sugar, but after those are done, there's not much point to playing on the harder difficulties.Why did I give this game a barely passing grade though? Because, like SS2013, there is this sense of hilarious illogicality, only this time, it's more subtle. Remember what I said about pushing the cup and the ingredients into each other, with the cup on its side? Well, it turns out that you can complete the game this way if you can really find no way to lift the cup and ingredients properly. Just imagine: your hot water and cold milk exist as orbs. You nudge the cup along and miraculously the liquid orbs somehow land up in your cup. And when you imagine that if this was an actual tea simulator, the tea would have long spilt by now! Oh well, glad to see that it's at least forgiving in that regard.And, unlike SS2013, you can flip the whole damn table if you screw up your tea in epic fashion. (╯°□°）╯︵ ┻━┻)It's enough for me, at least, to overlook its massive shortcomings. But only barely so.When to buy: I'd recommend picking this up as part of a bundle. Depending on your tolerance, skill and/or luck, this game will either have you ragequit after the first hour, or finish it within 2 and a half (like I did), which means very short gameplay time on average. Actually, scratch that. I'd recommend picking up SS2013 instead. You'll have a lot less frustration (and a lot more laughs).5.5/10Like indie games? My playtime: 3.4h (based on steam).Grindy Achievement: Yes (1 achievement; there is a way to speed it up, but it still takes around 1.5h).Optional Achievement: Yes (7 achievements).Difficult Achievement: Yes (1 achievement; can be more or less based on your patience).Developer Response: No (last response is in 12 Jun 2014, i think).IntroAmpu-Tea is a prosthetic hand simulator game to make a tea. Well, actually you can choose whethemaking a tea or screwing things up like flipping a table.GraphicsThis game is using 3D models and while i think that the help image looks great, the other does not. I think that it's still okay for such a cheap game though. I also want to add that the hot water and milk dispenser doesn't look informative enough. I don't know how to use it if i didn't watch a video for it. I even thought that i have to rotate the thing below the button which i think is a nightmare if i really have to do it.MusicThe music has a relaxing tone and is forgettable. I forgot how the music is right after i close the game. All sfxs are used appropriately.The gameI have a trouble in running the game in the first 30 minutes. I even have to restart my PC just to play it. The game will start in a main menu with a language select screen. After you select the language, the game will start. All controls are easy to understand but it's hard to be applied into the game. I don't know that you can turn the palm up and down after a few minutes.Even if you understand the controls, it's really hard to control the hand. Sometimes, the prosthetic will also move by itself (even if you don't move your mouse) after or when you are doing something. The hand itself also can't hold anything (even the hot water paper) and you can only hold the glass after sticking your hand to the glass' handle. Well, you actually can try to do it the other way, but you'll more likely fail to do it. This will become nightmare when you're trying to take a teabag or sugar. Luckily, the hand is sticky enough that the item will stick to your hand when it seems like you are not holding it. I also want to add that the same thing applies to the glass so you'll more likely have a hard time to take it off from your hand.The game itself can't really be completed unless you are patient enough and you'll obviously need to replay it a lot of times. Sadly, there is no reward after you complete the game. After you put the tea in the tray, there is nothing happening which make it seems like you have to make another tea.Pros:- If you think that getting frustated counts as one, so be it.Cons:- No ending- Weak hand- Sticky handConclusionThis is a prosthetic simulator game, although i can't really say that it's a simulator for the said thing because all you get is frustation in doing a simple task.Should you buy this game?No.Unless you want to get frustated when you are playing a game, that is.

												To start with, I would like to say that this is not a bad game exactly. Really, the main problem is that there is not much to it. As of now, I have earned 100% of the achievements, and the absurd one for launching the game 500 times easily accounted for the bulk of the time involved. The one really good part is that it's my first perfect game. All that is left to do at this point as far as the game is concerned is to endlessly try my hand at making cups of tea in the tea cups using any combo of milk and sugar along with the teabags and hot water. There are no other levels, tasks, or challenges. You're only given the one set-up to work with, with various levels of difficulty only coming into play via the complexity of the cup of tea being requested.Like other games of the sort, every movement required to actually achieve a task is absolutely painstaking, which is where the fine line between fun and frustration comes into play. Unfortunately, the glitches within the game do make things weigh slightly in favor of frustration, as the arm has a habit of going through things and getting stuck, plus other issues, along with the other intended quirks common in games like this, where it refuses to truly grab things, instead often flipping, dropping, or even breaking them.Having gotten the game in a bundle, I certainly wouldn't complain, as there is definitely some amount of fun to be had here. Nor would I dismiss the possibility of getting future games from the creators in the future, especially if they do something a bit bigger in scope. Yet, still, for what it currently is I cannot recommend buying it, unless you find it in a bundle with other games you want.

												A buggy, frustrating and weird version of Surgeon Simulator 2013 where you make tea with a non-functional hand. Just when you think that you've mastered the game you'll run into a bug that ruins your cup of tea. Everything weights the same, so everything flies upon contact. Unconfortable controls makes it impossible to grab things since your hand is so slow that the thing you're trying to grab moves as you're grabbing. You can't play offline, even if you have the game installed on your PC, which is the reason to why we install most games. The help screen keeps popping up when you restart, which is annoying and the game feels unfinished, considering the fact that you can go outside the kitchen, there's no real menu or even credits/ending. On the bright side, it was a funny experience at first and the references are kinda funny since they describe the opposite of what you're actually doing. The concept is also funny (just not done right) and you can tableflip. You also get Steam cards, which you can sell and get the value of the game back. You can also troll your friends by letting them try and laugh as they rage.Pros: - Fun first time experience- Funny concept- You can tableflip- Cool references- Steam Cards- Good for trolling friendsCons:- Disgusting, uncustomisable controls- You can't launch the game without internet- Buggy hand that sometimes has its own will- Everything has the same weight- Slow and weak hand that never grips- Annoying help screen that shows up all the time- Feels unfinished2/10 - Worth 0.74€ I guess. If you like Surgeon Simulator 2013, Probably Archery etc, you'll like this game the first few minutes and then hate it forever.

												Let me ask you a simple question.  Have you ever considered relearning how to move?  If so, Ampu-Tea will be your cup of tea  **snickers**.  I found myself getting frustrated with games like Surgeon Sim in the past, but this one only seems to bring joy, even in failure.  I found myself tensing up over the smallest tasks while trying to not spill the perfect tea I had just finished preparing, only to end up doing something absurd, like sweeping my newly acquired prosthesis across the table to get something out of my way.  This game is hilarious and fun as all hell, because every time you fail, it is your own fault for not knowing the ins and outs of your fake hand.  The ironic "Keep Calm and Carry On" flags and mugs everywhere remind me of how hard I had to focus to perform such a simple task.  I like to pack my tea full of teabags and see how many sugar cubes I can pick up in a single handful.  Long story short, This simple and frustrating game is a blast, especially for the price!

												What had seemed like an amusing and frustrating game quickly became a disappointment. Multiple times while grabbing or holding items, they would go through the solid portion of the robotic hand, or through other solid objects - attempting to grab tea cups that would then push through the back of the precariously positioned tea rack instead of knocking the rack over, bags of tea being in hand one moment and shooting up through the top of the hand the next, etc. At one point while playing, after 'pressing' the hot water button several times with no response, the water began to suddenly pop out (I would guess a 20 second or so lapse). I was tabbed out of the game in windowed mode while this was happening, and watched the hot water jug topple backwards. The hand was stationary well away from the table itself, panned out enough to see the table in its entirety while this was going on. All in all, the game could have some potential if it were polished and these errors were fixed. Unless those aren't errors and they are included purposely to make the game more 'challenging', in which case, that's poor judgment and a lack of creativity on part of the designers. Maybe if there's a patch I'd consider continuing to play, but as of now, I'd say I wasted my money and time.

												Ampu-Tea is a game for robot nerds, or tea nerds, or maybe just for nerds in general.This is a game for people with some patience. If you want an exciting shoot-'em-up gaming experience, then Ampu-Tea is not for you - walk away now! That's right, get out of here, non-nerd, and don't come back!Now that the neanderthal troglodytes have gone, let's get back to the review.The aim of the game is to make a nice mug of tea, using a robotic arm.There are a number of different instructions given to you, in order to make several mugs of tea.However, the basic tasks are to get a mug off a shelf and then add a tea bag, some sugar, and boiling water - and then serve on a tray (there are several variations of these tasks).To start the game, push "F1" for English (assuming that is the language you want, of course) - I mention that because I have had the start screen come up looking blurred once, and couldn't read the instruction in the top left corner to press F1.Press "H" to show or hide the help screen - very useful for learning the controls.Don't be surprised if you knock the entire shelf of mugs off the table - I was knocking everything over before I got used to how the robotic arm worked.Try to manoeuvre the mug into place in front of the tea-maker, before adding any tea or sugar, as it is easier to do everything with the mug already in place.Picking up the sugar cubes can be a real pain. Be prepared to drop them many times.Hint: Put the tray in its place first (in front of the tea-maker), so you can serve the tea on it later (otherwise you can make your mug of tea and then spill it when trying to put it onto a tray).The controls can take a bit of getting used to, but then it's much easier after that.A good experience for children who might have a talent for robotics.This game is for nerds only - it is recommended on that basis.

 THE GAME Ampu-Tea OVERIEW OF THE REVIEW Another 'simulator' game trying to riding the coat tails of Surgeon Simulator. This game is tea-dious, frustra-tea-ing, and lacks quali-tea. WHAT IT'S ABOUT Ampu-Tea is a Surgeon Simulator inspired game where you are an amputee fitted with a robotic arm and are tasked with making a cup of tea. In the style of SS, you control your robo-hand to attempt assembling different kinds of teas with the mouse and keyboard. The silly control style provides a challenge to this otherwise simple task and it will test your patience and eventually lead to some chaos. MY EXPERIENCE PLAYING THIS GAME Honestly, this game was a disappointment, and I wasn't even expecting anything from it. My experience playing this game was mostly frustration, thanks to the awful controls and mechanics.There is no grip to pick up anything, so I had to rely on pushing things across the table with the hand and trying to balance cup handles around the fingers. Speaking of the fingers, grabbing with them is incredibly slow and insensitive, along with the hand rotation. It took me half an hour of messing around just to make one cup of tea because of how fragile the mugs are, how easy it is to knock the shelf off the table, the painful journey of moving the cup from each station, and how easy it is to break the arm itself.There is little variety in what types of drinks you can make, and no story or real motivation to make them except for a sticky note. The game description mentions being the son of an Earl, but I found no connection to that in the game. The achievements are (despite the shocking controls) fairly easy to get, minus the one for opening the game 500 times which I did not have the patience for. There are trading cards, but I uninstalled the game before I had enough game time to collect them.The only highlight I managed to draw from this game was being able to flip the table in rage. 												Ampu-Tea is a game for robot nerds, or tea nerds, or maybe just for nerds in general.This is a game for people with some patience. If you want an exciting shoot-'em-up gaming experience, then Ampu-Tea is not for you - walk away now! That's right, get out of here, non-nerd, and don't come back!Now that the neanderthal troglodytes have gone, let's get back to the review.The aim of the game is to make a nice mug of tea, using a robotic arm.There are a number of different instructions given to you, in order to make several mugs of tea.However, the basic tasks are to get a mug off a shelf and then add a tea bag, some sugar, and boiling water - and then serve on a tray (there are several variations of these tasks).To start the game, push "F1" for English (assuming that is the language you want, of course) - I mention that because I have had the start screen come up looking blurred once, and couldn't read the instruction in the top left corner to press F1.Press "H" to show or hide the help screen - very useful for learning the controls.Don't be surprised if you knock the entire shelf of mugs off the table - I was knocking everything over before I got used to how the robotic arm worked.Try to manoeuvre the mug into place in front of the tea-maker, before adding any tea or sugar, as it is easier to do everything with the mug already in place.Picking up the sugar cubes can be a real pain. Be prepared to drop them many times.Hint: Put the tray in its place first (in front of the tea-maker), so you can serve the tea on it later (otherwise you can make your mug of tea and then spill it when trying to put it onto a tray).The controls can take a bit of getting used to, but then it's much easier after that.A good experience for children who might have a talent for robotics.This game is for nerds only - it is recommended on that basis.

I don't know why this game has negative reviews, apart from two reasons:.The "Obsessive Tea Drinker" achievement (which requires you to play the game 500 times).The game makes you rageI had fun with my time on Ampu-Tea, it's a great game - and no, it's not a rip off of Surgeon Sim, it's in a way deep down, better. I enjoyed the rage of being one step closer to earning that good ol' achievement where you have to make a 'cuppa'. I had fun in and out of every aspect of this game, it sure was challenging - even on the easy difficulty, but that adds to the fun! So what if there is a few minor bugs? Kudos to DjArcas & Kiss Ltd for making sure there was no major bugs, anyway. I recommend you get Ampu-Tea to everybody, for it is a great game, and a challenging one too. I enjoyed collecting all the achievements etc, and I think you will too. Overall: 9/10.
